Hmm... I have retested this but it seems the behavior I described here is wrong, and usage of undef just leaves the parameter "unamanged".

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
I reconsidered my position and now agree with the approach taken in this patch. But this now suggests it might be worth merging this change into https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-cinder/+/834588.

I apologize if I'm confusing things or causing churn.

I'm afraid I've not yet fully understood your concerns.

For netapp_copyoffload_tool_path option, no default value is defined by oslo.config interface, which makes the parameter "default to None". The current netapp driver treats None and '' in the same manner, and disables copyoffload feature for both these values.

The current default is just redundant because it always sets the optional parameter, in a wired format which eventually results in service default.


> If the goal is to avoid adding empty values to cinder.conf then how about something like this:

I don't agree with this. This eventually results in missing netapp_copyoffload_tool_path, which is effectively same as the current change, and leaves the parameter unmanaged if a user set the parameter once but remove that later.

Dumping my test results for reference.
 https://paste.opendev.org/show/bCrE2Shxso0FStLPVnD8/

If a parameter is set to undef then puppet automatically replaces the parameter by its default value.
 https://paste.opendev.org/show/bQbJ3akBzrnNbA2TPBRc/

Because of this behavior, the current implementation is effectively same as what you wrote.

- If netapp_vserver is not set, then it defaults to $::os_service_default and is removed (effectively same as ensure => absent)
- If netapp_vserver is set to undef, puppet replaces the undef value by the default value which is $::os_service_default and remove the parameter
- If netapp_vserver is set to $::os_service_default then the parameter is removed from cinder.conf

Oh, OK, I misread the situation. I incorrectly thought you were previously saying $::os_service_default  was not properly unmanaging the parameters, which is why I tested my approach. Howevever, I now see that $::os_service_default *does* do the right thing (L76 of your pastebin).

So I'm OK using $::os_service_default, and you can consider merging that into the other patch.
Thanks for checking ! I've updated the patch.
Couple of comments, the patch looks good. Thanks.

nova/tests/fixtures/nova.py.message: Probably worth adding a couple words here to indicate the potential for a retry, especially if you cap it. Maybe the potential failure should have been noted here too, but...
Yeah, since whoever wrote this code left it out in the first place :P
Sounds like a good idea, will add mention of the retry and failure potential.

It seems a little concerning to make this a hard and infinite loop. If we starve out any other threads or fail to eventually give up we could be introducing a deadlock here. I think two threads that hit this exactly right could be tossing the global state back and forth between their setting, checking, resetting, checking, etc.

Is there any reason not to cap this at some reasonable retry value (perhaps maybe only try twice?) to avoid that? It also seems like we want some schedule-yielding delay in the retry, like a sleep(1) in the except handler to further give a chance for other things to progress before we retry the same thing again. If you use something like "for retry in range(0, 3)" then you could also sleep(retry) to increase the backoff from "no wait but schedule" to longer delays.

Hm, OK. I had been thinking one would have to progress ahead of the other upon a retry but I think you are right that if the other retries at the "right" time it could go on again. And good point about adding a schedule-yield in here, I missed that. I'll change this to cap retries and do a sleep().

It's a classic dining philosophers problem where you have to do two things to proceed, along with your dining partner. Kinda has to be that way because we need the actual work to be reentrant (hence the reader lock) and probably the reason I initially punted until it actually became a problem. But yeah, in general, good to add something to break up a tight loop like this so that something changes.

This is okay I guess, but why not just put a break after L507? That further asserts and exposes the "we expect to run this once unless interrupted" behavior. We'd never want to accidentally loop if we make it that far. If you convert this to for(i in retries) then the break will fit better too.
No I definitely agree it's better, I just didn't do it for some unknown reason ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
Ack, just seems a little cleaner to me. I dunno why I said "this is okay I _guess_" ... it's clearly okay as it is, just a little neater to use break I think :)
Hm, I don't know why I didn't do that. I guess I didn't think of it for some reason. Will change it.

OK, I think this is fixing the problem when the fixture detects that the target changed due to a racing thread. But I'm not sure what will happen with the racing thread. That thread set a target that is now unset by this fixture.
Ahh OK. Both thread going through this same code path. So both will apply the new retry. Cool. Thanks for the explanation.

Hm... so each thread has a 'desired' cell it wants to target and if Thread A sets to cell1 and then Thread B sets to cell0 "at the same time" then Thread A will detect the change at L488 and set it back to cell1 and try again. Now Thread B resumes and enters locked section L487 and since its 'desired' cell is cell0 and Thread A had set _last_ctxt_mgr = cell1, it will detect the change at L488 and then retry and set it back to cell0 and then check _last_ctxt_mgr != 'desired' again and when it matches, proceed to the DB call.

It seems like racing threads will always retry and end up getting their 'desired' cell. Let me know if you see any gaps that I missed.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Agree with the nits, but +1 otherwise
If the plan is to say << OpenStack 2022.2 ("Aardvark") >> and the name of the series can continue to be used in the release tooling (in particular in the stable branch name) I have far less concerns.
Overall I am +1 on the intention.  Think the nits need to be addressed.

TLDR: I'm actually concerned that having two number-based versioning schemes in parallel would confuse people more than it helps them.

OpenStack actually started with what this proposal proposes, (using numbers for official release names, and codenames for fun/marketing/dev purposes). Then as we added more components we allowed them to use different version numbers, while the "integrated release" was just using the name. So you would release "Nova 24.0.0 and Swift 2.28.0 as part of OpenStack Xena", have Neutron 19.0.0 in the stable/xena branch, and emit release announcements like "oslo.policy 3.8.3 (xena)".

With this proposal, you get more complex statements like "Nova 25.0.0 and Swift 2.29.0 as part of OpenStack 2022.1", stable branches that are called stable/2022.1 for versions like Neutron 20.0.0, or my personal favorite, release announcements that say "oslo.db 11.2.0 (2022.1)".

I understand that it's sometimes difficult to map a named release to its original release date, but it seems like an easier challenge than explaining why you have stable branches called stable/2022.1 tracking a neutron release numbered 20.0.0.

To be fair, this was the initial approach (<year>.<release_count_within_the_year>) to identify project versions/releases until Kilo. With Liberty we started to express how “old” was each individual project. I don’t remember the motivation, but considering the time period, it was probably related to the “big tent” and maturity “tags”.

I understand Thierry's concerns, but in my view this proposal helps to clarify and map a release to a point in time. Something that we lost in Kilo - 2015 (yes, I needed to go check when Kilo was released).

I think this is even more important now that we will start again with the alphabet (for the release name) and we are discussing a different release support cadence.

In terms of individual project versions I don’t think they need to be changed. In this case “Nova 27.0.0 is part of OpenStack release 2023.1” code named “Aardvark”.
proposal lgtm, 1 comment on open voting to all community members

On the stable branch, are we going to do it with the version number or name? stable/2022.1 or stable/Axxx ? I think we need to clarify that too.

I know it will create some confusion but at the same time it will clear out the timelines and how old my OpenStack version is (without going to check the release date of old releases). 

I agree on individual component versions are already confusing with the OpenStack main release and i do not think changing the OpenStack main release with a name or number or both add any more confusion.

From my point of view, this is touching another subject which is versioning of different components. From my perspective as a deployer and knowing other deployers, I can say that the fact that different components have different version numbers is confusing already so it's not really made worse for practical purposes.
Looks good other than then rendering of the examples!
This could be a good way to differentiate between the first alphabet series and the second time around, which will be useful for things like the release automation. So +1 to the idea.
I am good with the latest iteration here.

Thanks, Belmiro!

Two questions/comments:

- Will having a '.' in the name create issues down the line, e.g. when it comes to URLs (such as per release repos)?

- Would it make sense to take 'upgradability' somehow into account in the name given the proposed
  tick/tock scheme (I know tick/tock is not approved yet)? With .1 and .2, and assuming .1 is the tick release the rules would be sth like:

  yearN.1 (tick) -> yearN.2 (tock), yearN+1.1 (tick)
  yearN.2 (tock) -> yearN+1.1 (tick)
  
  which is certainly better than what we would end up with the previous naming scheme, but I was wondering if that could be made more explicit. (I do not have a good suggestion for this, though.)
This gives us an unambiguous way to refer to each release; makes sense to me.

I don't think we have to say "after Zed" here, because if I understand this correctly, you're not proposing this as an actual versioning designator as it was in the past (the Kilo release of cinder was version 2015.1.0 tagged on 2015-04-30, whereas the Xena release of cinder was version 19.0.0 tagged on 2021-10-06).  So we could just agree that the way we want to refer to releases in official communication follows the scheme you outline here.  Thus, we can start referring to historical releases as:

  OpenStack 2021.2 "Xena"
  ...
  OpenStack 2012.1 "Essex"
  OpenStack 2011.3 "Diablo"
  OpenStack 2011.2 "Cactus"
  OpenStack 2011.1 "Bexar"
  OpenStack 2010.1 "Austin"

and the OpenStack 2022.1 "Yoga" release will contain cinder 20.0.0.
I agree with Belmiro here. and I do not think we should reflect this for past releases. Project versioning is completely different and we are not touching those in this proposal.

The proposal is to change the release identification/name, not project versions. Until now, releases only have a name ("Austin", "Bexar", ...). The proposal is that starting with the "restart" of the alphabet (after Zed) we can start referring to releases also with "yearN.X". Example: OpenStack 2023.1 Axxxx

Not sure if we can/should reflect this in past releases.
When we changed the project versioning, we continue to refer to earlier projects versions using the "old" schema (For example: 2015.1).

After Zed, we will have the release "2023.1 Axxxx" with the Cinder version 22.0.0

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message:
My only problem with this approach is that, if the lock moves around to another worker (e.g shutting down the neutron-server where this lock was held) the new worker who acquired a valid lock will run the sync() again.

If the mode is "repair" it will make changes to OVN NB DB while the cluster is being used, other changes will be coming from the API which could conflict with the sync() specially if it's a environment with many resources created. So I wonder if we should just "return" in case there's no valid lock here or if we should "raise periodics.NeverAgain()" and never run sync() again. 

Thoughts ?

hi lucas, here's what I'm worried about: if we "raise periodics.NeverAgain()", we may not be able to trigger synchronization by restarting neutron
eg:
three neutron-server 
neutron-server-1 no lock
neutron-server-2 has lock
neutron-server-3 no lock

step 1:
restart neutron-server-1, neutron-server-1 can not get the lock, not sync.
now is,
neutron-server-1 no lock
neutron-server-2 has lock
neutron-server-3 no lock

step 2:
restart neturon-server-2, neutron-server-3 will get lock, but not sync, and neutron-server-2 can not get the lock, not sync.
now is,
neutron-server-1 no lock
neutron-server-2 no lock
neutron-server-3 has lock

step 3:
restart neutron-server-3 will like 'step 2', no neutron-server sync.

generally, we need two kinds of synchronization:
case 1: there is a problem with the code, causing out of synchronization. in this case, the synchronization data is generally small. Even if it is run several times, it should have little impact.
case 2: the NB database is abnormal and the data has been deleted. at this time, the most important thing is to start sync quickly.

So I think it's better to “return" if don't has the lock.
lucas, what your thoughts?

[2] https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/latest/config/project.html#attr-project.default-branch

manifests/resource/authtoken.pp.message: I noticed this usage is completely useless, because memcached_servers takes items like <ip>:<port> and these elements are never recognized as IPv6 addresses...

My point is that this usage of inet6_prefix in puppet-keystone has been "incomplete". It has worked effectively only if memcached_servers is a list of <host>, and it has never worked if the parameter is set by list of <host>:<port>.

TripleO has never leveraged this function call in puppet-keystone but it calls the inet6_prefix function in its manifest and passes the complete memcached_servers.

Even if we implement this parameter, users still need to set the new parameter correctly. This does not make much difference from the current status that users need to compose up the parameter value correctly, IMO, while it requires change in all modules, which involves some effort.

I tend to leave the current implementation inside module(or even deprecate the internal conversion) and implement a new help function like os_memcache_server so that users can compose the parameter value more easily. This would allow us to implement some variations, for example to determine whether inet6 prefix is required, so that we can use the same function for different parameters like [oslo_cache] memcache_servers
Hmm... I might be reading the code wrongly. Let me recheck...

The use of inet6_prefix() is the old behaviour. What is new in this change is the "memcached_ipv6" bool param and the use of inet6_prefix_any() which works for <hostname>:<ip>. inet6_prefix() was good for years, until tripleo switched to use hostnames ...
OK so I confirmed I was wrong. Current logic can handle the <host>:<port> format. I'll give it another thought

It seems memcached accepts servers without port and the port defaults to 11211 in that case. So this implementation is currently valid if only ips are listed, which is not useful in tripleo's use case.

I'm still wondering how beneficial to have this new function.

The current implementation results in having two similar but incomplete functions.

inet6_prefix
 - works for ipv4/ipv6 when ip is used
 - works for ipv4 when hostname is used

inet6_prefix_any
 - works for ipv4/ipv6 when ip is used
 - works for ipv6 when hostname is used

I've drafted a potential solution to introduce such flag with backward compatibility kept.
 https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/puppet-openstacklib/+/834175

Right, it would be nice to have one that could handle both.

While I kind of like the idea of using resolve as done in your patch, it would not work in case puppet runs in some build system which cannot resolve the names.

If we could have inet6_prefix have a kw argument like (list, prefix_hostname=True) Not sure if that would be possible without breaking bacward compatibility.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: What is the current behaviour implemented by this change? It would be good if there was a longer description of what this PS does as I have lost track. Does it write to --dir and merge if there is a --force flag? It would be useful for users if relevant part of the user docs was updated too. Thanks.

As it is now, whenever a user executes "openstack coe cluster config <cluster-name>" the new cluster config is merged with the existing config file that exists in the given directory.

This is especially useful because we can do something like this: "openstack coe cluster config --dir ~/.kube/config <cluster-name>" and then we can use "kubectl config get-contexts" like in google cloud.

If "--force" is used not the whole file is overwritten, just the cluster that we are working on. To be more specific, Python-MagnumClient loads the old config as a dict, deletes everything that corresponds to our cluster and then adds the new values.

I will need to update the docs as you said in order to make everything more clear.

Can we achieve the same using environment variables? We already specify ERL_EPMD_ADDRESS and ERL_EPMD_PORT in rabbitmq-env.conf. There's also RABBITMQ_NODE_IP_ADDRESS

https://www.rabbitmq.com/configure.html#supported-environment-variables

Based on https://www.rabbitmq.com/networking.html, I think we can use these for the port range:

RABBITMQ_CTL_DIST_PORT_MIN
RABBITMQ_CTL_DIST_PORT_MAX

My guess is, that RABBITMQ_NODE_IP_ADDRESS is only used for client connections (read: messaging queue clients) but not for inter cluster communication, because this can apparently not be set inside rabbitmq as it is a setting of the erlang/beam vm.

Quote: "The range used by RabbitMQ can also be controlled via two configuration keys:

    kernel.inet_dist_listen_min in the classic config format only
    kernel.inet_dist_listen_max in the classic config format only"

See: https://www.rabbitmq.com/networking.html#epmd-inet-dist-port-range

This suggests to me this port ranges can only be configured via classic config format, but I must admit the language is ambigious (at least to me, a non native speaker).

It is not really documented, if you can set the cluster interface via environment variables, the best I could find is this google groups/ rabbitmq ml message from 2014:

https://groups.google.com/g/rabbitmq-users/c/6dpj7NeJswI

where Simon McMullen says:

On 14/07/2014 4:19AM, hung david wrote:
> But it seems there's no option to bind clustering protocol to a specific
> interface. The default is to bind to all interface.
> I just want clustering protocol to bind to my LAN only. So is there any
> way I can do that?
> Thanks.

It's an Erlang feature rather than a RabbitMQ one, but maybe we should
document it.

You can set the kernel config item "inet_dist_use_interface", e.g.:

[{kernel, [{inet_dist_use_interface, {192, 168, 1, 100}}]},
{rabbit, [{tcp_listeners, ...}]}].

See http://erlang.org/doc/man/kernel_app.html 


So in short: I will try to test this in our CI (which might take some time) and report back.

Another question: Would you refrain from making this setting truly configurable? I know it was not really configurable before, but this would make my life a whole lot easier.

If you wish I can split this up, and firstly reinstate the old behaviour of defaulting to the api_interface and submit a second changeset which makes it configurable.

Hi John,

Thank you for reviewing this commit! Unfortunately I do not yet have access to a system that automatically loads the bnxt_en and bnxt_re drivers, due to hardware unavailability.

However, I confirmed using a bootstrapped VM that the kdump initramfs image (i.e., /boot/initramfs-*kdump.img") does not include the bnxt_en and bnxt_re drivers, when this patch is applied. I also verified that dracut was passed the correct arguments when preparing the kdump initramfs image:

Yes, I agree we should "publish the kernel-headers-5.10 RPM file to a CENGN and then include it in the layer package lists."  there is not kernel-headers-5.10 RPM file to replace kernel-headers-4.18.   and I found mlnx-tools also build out with kernel-headers-4.18.
Ah, good point. I did not search, but I doubt that a relevant bug report exists. I will double check internally and on Launchpad, and if necessary I will file an internal bug report about this.

I tried adding "BuildRequires: kernel%{?bt_ext}-headers" (not "-devel") to libbnxt_re's spec file without Jiping's suggested fix, but this approach did not work, as the kernel-headers-4.18 already installed in the chroot file system satisfied this build dependency.

I did not try using "BuildRequires: kernel%{?bt_ext}-devel", because libbnxt_re does not really depend on the kernel's development headers, only the user-space-facing headers are necessary.

I also wondered why kernel-headers-4.18 is in the chroot file system at all. It is included in the compiler and distro layers' package lists. A real solution would perhaps be to periodically/automatically publish the kernel-headers-5.10 RPM file to a CENGN and then include it in the layer package lists. Given the impact of this approach, I will not attempt it at this point.

As a last resort, I have verified that adding "BuildRequires: kernel%{?bt_ext}-headers >= 5.10" to libbnxt_re's spec file resolves this issue as well. I will take this approach for now.

(I linked the internal issue to this one as well.)

The packages with the conflicting headers are:

kernel-headers-4.18.0-147.3.1.el8_1.x86_64
rdma-core-devel-55mlnx37-1.55103.tis.5.x86_64

This is surprising, because rdma-core-devel should have been built against the 5.10 kernel's headers, but it was built against the 4.18 kernel's headers, at least according to:

```
$ grep kernel- ../results/${USER}-*/rdma-core-55mlnx37-1.55103.tis.5/installed_pkgs.log 

kernel-headers-4.18.0-147.3.1.el8_1.x86_64 1578096985 4857545 0f96105d85a5357c5fa75760c085b639 installed
```

I think that we have a deeper problem here.
Really needs to be a starlingx bug report if it affects starlingx.

Thank you, Jiping!

After numerous test/trial builds (which took a lot of time), I confirmed that Jiping's suggestion fixes the issue with libbnxt_re.

I later found that the libbnxt_re build failure is an intermittent one: The build system tries to build libbnxt_re repeatedly until kernel{,-rt}-headers becomes available, after which the kernel{,-rt}-headers package is installed into the chroot/mock file system, and the libbnxt_re build succeeds.

All this to say, this is mainly an efficiency issue.

Another untested fix could be to add "BuildRequires: kernel%{?bt_ext}-devel" to the libbnxt_re spec file, so that the dependency is explicit. This would admittedly only resolve the issue for libbnxt_re. I am testing this approach for libbnxt_re.

The build failure is caused by kernel-4.18's headers, I think. The following two files appear in the chroot/mock file system:

- /usr/include/rdma/rdma_user_ioctl_cmds.h
- /usr/include/infiniband/ib_user_ioctl_verbs.h

These files cause a conflict between themselves:

```
BUILDSTDERR: In file included from ./src/rc-compat/v35/cmd_ioctl.h:40:0,
BUILDSTDERR:                  from ./src/rc-compat/v35/driver.h:42,
BUILDSTDERR:                  from src/main.h:55,
BUILDSTDERR:                  from src/verbs.c:56:
BUILDSTDERR: /usr/include/rdma/rdma_user_ioctl_cmds.h:87:6: error: nested redefinition of 'enum rdma_driver_id'
BUILDSTDERR:  enum rdma_driver_id {
BUILDSTDERR:       ^
BUILDSTDERR: /usr/include/rdma/rdma_user_ioctl_cmds.h:87:6: error: redeclaration of 'enum rdma_driver_id'
BUILDSTDERR: In file included from /usr/include/infiniband/verbs_api.h:66:0,
BUILDSTDERR:                  from /usr/include/infiniband/verbs.h:48,
BUILDSTDERR:                  from ./src/rc-compat/v35/driver.h:40,
BUILDSTDERR:                  from src/main.h:55,
BUILDSTDERR:                  from src/verbs.c:56:
BUILDSTDERR: /usr/include/infiniband/ib_user_ioctl_verbs.h:232:6: note: originally defined here
BUILDSTDERR:  enum rdma_driver_id {
BUILDSTDERR:       ^

```

Here is a command that shows this for the first header file, executed relative to the root of the chroot/mock file system:
```
$ rpm --root $(pwd) --dbpath  var/lib/rpm/ -q \
         -f /usr/include/rdma/rdma_user_ioctl_cmds.h
kernel-headers-4.18.0-147.3.1.el8_1.x86_64
```

This issue is resolved (I think) when the kernel headers for the v5.10 kernel are installed in the chroot/mock file system, because I do not recall encountering this error with monolithic builds.

All this to say, I will attempt to resolve this issue by adding a BuildRequires for kernel{,-rt}-devel and/or kmod-bnxt_en.

centos_pkg_dirs_rt.message: Not specific to this review, but I've often wondered about these userspace packages.  We seem to build them in both std and rt, but the rt compiled versions don't end up with -rt in their name.  So the rt compiled ones just bulldoze over the std compiled ones.  We're at the mercy of the std and rt kernels being the same in terms of the headers.  Correct me if I'm wrong, and also is this anything to really worry about?

Thank you for the feedback, Scott!

Jim, resolving this issue properly will likely be a larger effort. Would you be agreeable to fixing this issue after this work is merged? I can talk to Mark tomorrow about the need for a clean-up.

This will also have a repercussions in case we would like to have the standard and real-time kernels installed at the same time in the future.
This may be something that we should engage Scott in, get his thoughts.

While waiting for Scott, I have investigated this a bit. It appears that the "std" variants of the packages actually take precedence.

In the example below, the ISO image was built with "build-iso --skip-sign" to prevent build-iso from modifying the RPM packages by adding signatures. After "build-iso --skip-sign", I checked  which variants (std vs. rt) of the rdma-core and libbnxt_re packages are preferred by inspecting the md5 checksums, and it looks like the std variants are preferred. This is true even for rdma-core, whose "rt" variant has a later release field value (".tis.7") than the one for "std", whose release field is ".tis.5.".

```
$ md5sum ${MY_BUILD_DIR}/export/dist/isolinux/Packages/{libbnxt_re*,rdma-core}*.rpm  ${MY_BUILD_DIR}/*/rpmbuild/RPMS/{libbnxt_re,rdma-core}*.x86_64.rpm | grep -v -e -debuginfo  -e -devel | sort -V | sed -e "s@${MY_BUILD_DIR}/@@"


6a98b2659c0a209c35dd0495d16e044f  export/dist/isolinux/Packages/rdma-core-55mlnx37-1.55103.tis.5.x86_64.rpm
6a98b2659c0a209c35dd0495d16e044f  std/rpmbuild/RPMS/rdma-core-55mlnx37-1.55103.tis.5.x86_64.rpm

8a4b20cec806b9d8a2b229ae675703c2  rt/rpmbuild/RPMS/libbnxt_re-220.0.5.0-rhel7u9.tis.1.x86_64.rpm
86e6ae07308fce8a293cedec127dc99e  rt/rpmbuild/RPMS/rdma-core-55mlnx37-1.55103.tis.7.x86_64.rpm

a78b87213a2460ec1a058125df8c23a0  export/dist/isolinux/Packages/libbnxt_re-220.0.5.0-rhel7u9.tis.1.x86_64.rpm
a78b87213a2460ec1a058125df8c23a0  std/rpmbuild/RPMS/libbnxt_re-220.0.5.0-rhel7u9.tis.1.x86_64.rpm
```

All this to say, the rt packages do not appear to override the std packages.

However, the original concern regarding the potential for issues with different kernel headers/APIs stands.

Hi, I think you made a good observation. I was not sure about the need for duplicating user-space packages between std and rt as well, and I started to think that I should remove the entry for libbnxt_re.

I just ran a grep for bt_ext in the userspace directory, and I saw the following:

```
userspace/mellanox/mlnx-tools/centos/meta_patches/0001-Support-STX-system.patch
userspace/mellanox/mstflint/centos/meta_patches/0001-Support-STX-system.patch
userspace/mellanox/rdma-core/centos/meta_patches/0001-Support-STX-system.patch
```

However, on a closer inspection, none of the packages use the bt_ext spec variable in the Name field of the respective spec file. I agree that this is a bit concerning.

Do you agree that we should open a bug report about this issue? I can open one if you agree. I should also note that I do not have the full historical context here.

In addition, I think you spotted something important: I forgot to modify the Name: field to add the potential -rt suffix as necessary, so this commit will really cause the rt variant of libbnxt_re to override the standard variant of libbnxt_re, I think.

I will address both issues with respect to libbnxt_re:

- I will remove libbnxt_re from the centos_pkg_dirs_rt file and test the result.
- I will ensure that the patch for libbnxt_re's spec file adds the -rt suffix, in case it becomes necessary to include this package in the rt build, to avoid hidden surprises.

Thanks again!

I agree that the -rt extension should be part of the user space package name.  You'll probably need to make 'filter-out-from*' files changes.  You may also need to add a common 'provides' if other packages (generic, not rt or std) require the one in question.

I had prepared the following comment, but Mark posted his before I finished the tests for my other comment. Posting it for the sake of completeness.

---

As mentioned in my internal e-mail to Mark, I started to think that this issue may have limited impact.

The preempt-rt and standard kernels have the same base version (5.10.99), and my understanding is that the preempt-rt patches should not change the user-space-facing headers, especially those related to Infiniband/RDMA. Of course, I might be missing something important, so please let me know what you think.

The preempt-rt patchset does not modify the kernel's UAPI headers. (take a look for example at https://mirrors.edge.kernel.org/pub/linux/kernel/projects/rt/5.10/patch-5.10.106-rt64.patch.gz)

Userspace application should *only* be makeing use of the uapi headers and thus do not need a standard and -rt variant.

For userspace libraries like glibc/musl and such, they rely on the kernel's stable ABI promise, which the preempt-rt patchset doesn't break.

This is how Paul uses a Ubuntu rootfs to do preempt-rt kernel development, or how we can switch the normal Debian kernel for the Debian -rt kernel variant without having to worry about any special handling for userspace.

Out-of-tree kernel modules would be the only exception and we will have to review them but long term we should move the OOT kernel module code into the kernel, an activity we have kicked off and will have a storyboard for soon.
